items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources and Vida L. Branner,
Director, Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m.
Receive and Sunshine the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From
California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 to East Side Union High School District
					 
	                                    
	 
The District has received a copy of the California School Employees Association (CSEA), Chapter 187 initial bargaining proposal, a copy of which is attached.  Per the Government Code, the District must receive and sunshine in open session the initial proposal of any bargaining unit prior to commencing negotiations.  Administration recommends that the Board receive, sunshine, and take any public comment on the initial proposal of the California School Employees Association (CSEA), Chapter 187.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive, sunshine and take any public comment on the initial proposal of the California School Employees Association (CSEA), Chapter 187.
	 
	 
	 
	 
CALIFORNIA SCHOOL EMPLOYEES ASSOCIATION
Sunshine Proposal
For the Successor Contract Commencing 7/1/12
June 25, 2012
	 
The California School Employees Association (CSEA) and its local Chapter 187 are submitting its “initial bargaining proposals” in accordance with section 3547 of the Government Code for the 2012/2013 re-opener negotiations.
	 
CSEA respectfully submits the following bargaining proposals:
	 
Article 14 (Transfer, Promotions, and Filling of Vacancies) 
CSEA has an interest to provide bargaining unit members with the first opportunity to fill vacancies.
	 
Article 15 (Compensation)
CSEA has an interest to compensate bargaining unit members for utilizing their bilingual skills. 
	 
Article 16 (Benefits)
CSEA has an interest to enhance the District Contribution to the health benefit plan.
	 
Article 16 (Holidays)
CSEA has an interest to add an additional holiday.
	 
Article 20 (Hours and Overtime)
CSEA has an interest to discuss, clarify and amend the Bus Driver language.
	 
Appendix J
CSEA has an interest to discuss, clarify and amend the process to use Catastrophic Leave.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m.
Regarding Tentative Successor Agreement with the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO, July 1, 2012 – June 30, 2013, and Disclosure of Major Provisions of Tentative Agreement (AB1200) 
					 
	 
	 
In accordance with Assembly Bill 1200 requiring school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	 
Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO.  The District and the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO reached a tentative agreement on June 14, 2012.  The tentative agreement was ratified by San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO on August 1, 2012.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board accept any comment on the proposed Tentative Agreement with the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO, July 1, 2012 – June 30, 2013.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:

SUBJECT:
Ratify and Approve Tentative Successor Agreement with the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO, July 1, 2012 – June 30, 2013, and Disclosure of Major Provisions of Tentative Agreement (AB1200)
					 
	 
	 
Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO.  The District and the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO reached a tentative agreement on June 14, 2012.  The tentative agreement was ratified by San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO on August 1, 2012.  We are submitting this agreement to the Board of Trustees for approval.
	 
In addition, provisions of AB1200 require that the school districts disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing was held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As per the attached AB1200 document
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Adult Education funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees, per compliance with AB1200, ratify and approve the tentative agreement between the East Side Union High School District and the San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, AFL-CIO, July 1, 2012 – June 30, 2013.

items.item_details:
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Resolution to Support
Schools & Local Public Safety Protection Act (Proposition 30)
and 
Our Children Our Future: Local Schools and Early Education Investment Act (Proposition 38)
	 
Resolution No: 2012/2013-01
	 
WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District Board of Education is committed to making policy and financial decisions that enable the school district to provide quality educational programs and services to the school-age children of our community; and
	 
WHEREAS, since the onset of the state’s fiscal crisis in 2008, public schools statewide have experienced unprecedented funding reductions and apportionment deferrals totaling more than $20 billion; and 
	 
WHEREAS, California public schools now rank 47th out of the 50 states in per-pupil spending. Moreover, more than 40,000 educators have been laid off from California public schools since 2008, impacting the quality of the educational programs delivered to students; and
	 
WHEREAS, East Side Union High School District has implemented the following cuts in order to stay fiscally solvent: $51,273,000; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the school funding crisis is at historic proportions with 188 school districts certifying possible difficulty in meeting their financial obligations over the next two years; and
	 
WHEREAS, the 2012-13 state budget is predicated on voter approval in November 2012 of the Schools & Local Public Safety Protection Act (Prop 30), without which schools will receive additional mid-year funding reductions that will result in additional cuts in services and programs to students; and 
	 
WHEREAS, Proposition 30 and Proposition 38 will direct billions of dollars to public schools, providing an important short-term funding solution that may allow for the restoration of some student programs and services; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the California School Boards Association, representing nearly 1,000 school district governing boards and regional educational agencies, supports the passage of both Proposition 30 (Schools & Local Public Safety Protection Act) and Proposition 38 (Our Children Our Future: Local Schools and Early Education Investment Act); and
	 
BE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District Governing Board joins CSBA and school districts around the state in supporting both funding measures and proudly joins the Stand Up For Education campaign to urge the Legislature to work with CSBA and other education leaders to identify long-term adequate funding solutions for public schools; and
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that this body, the East Side Union High School District, supports the passage of both Proposition 30 and Proposition 38 because each provides needed revenue to public schools. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 23rd day of August 2012 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California, by the following vote of the Board:
	 
AYES: ________
	 
NOES: ________
ABSENT: ________
	 
ABSTENTIONS: ________
	 
	 
I certify that the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on August 23, 2012.
	 
_________________________
	J. Manuel Herrera, Clerk
	ESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Rogelio Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel, Rehon & Roberts
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Proposed First Amendment to Superintendent’s Contract
	 
	 
	 
Counsel recommends that the Section 5 of the Superintendent’s Contract (“Fringe Benefits”) be modified so that it is consistent with all Administrative team members and consistent with past and existing District practice.
	 
Section 5 of the Superintendent’s Contract currently provides as follows:
	 
“FRINGE BENEFITS. In addition to the Superintendent’s base salary, the Superintendent shall also be provided with the same fringe benefits, including but not limited to healthcare benefits, that are granted to the District’s certificated management personnel as may be amended, changed, or modified by approval or resolution of the Board for such administrative team members.”
	 
Currently, per Board approval, existing certificated administrators’ (cabinet level) contracts grant the same fringe benefits, including healthcare benefits, granted to all management team members, and such administrators may, per contract, exercise the option to convert the value of the fringe benefits package into a dollar amount equivalent to the premium paid by the District and to have the amount included in salary and paid out over twelve (12) equal monthly installments, in which case the administrator shall be responsible for obtaining any and all such fringe benefits at his/her sole cost and expense; provided however, that amount shall not be included as base pay for the purposes of receiving any COLAs (cost of living allowances) or for the purposes of calculating such person’s buy-out amount in the event of termination without cause as per the contract.
	 
Superintendent Funk’s contract (Section 5) grants him the same fringe benefits as administrative team members which would include the right to exercise the above option.  Modifying Section 5 of the Superintendent’s contract to incorporate the identical contract language will clarify his right to that option and will establish uniformity in the contract language among all administrative team members.
	 
	 
	 
Funding Source:
General Fund
	 
Fiscal Impact:
None
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the First Amendment to Contract as proposed.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the First Amendment to Contract as proposed.

Item:  11.04
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nominations for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic. The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting at the San Francisco Westin St. Francis Hotel on November 28 and 29, 2012. Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a CSBA board member and the nominee must be board member from a CSBA member district or county office of education. Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference. 
	 
The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.

TO:

FROM:

SUBJECT:

For the Board's review, attached is a draft letter to the Board of Trustees and Superintendent of the Santa Clara County Office of Education, which is in response to their proposed resolution to exempt Rocketship 8 Charter School from zoning requirements.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.02
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Rogelio Ruiz, Legal Counsel, Rehon & Roberts
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Status of Piedmont Hills High School Auxiliary Gym Project; Approval of Termination of Contract with BCI Builders, Inc. for Construction of Project and/or Termination of Contractor's Right to Perform the Work of the Contract; Delegation of Authority to Administration to Terminate Contract and/or Contractor's Right to Perform the Work of the Contract and to Tender Claim to Surety Under Project Performance Bond
	 
	 
	 
Project Background and Status
		 
On April 21, 2011, the Board took action to award the above construction project contract to BCI Builders, Inc. ("BCI") in the original contract amount of $3,860,000.00. In connection with the contract BCI posted a Performance Bond in favor of the District for the full contract amount.
		 
A Notice to Proceed was issued to BCI on May 5, 2011.  At the time, the total contract time was estimated to be 425 calendar days with an estimated completion date of July 7, 2012.  That completion date has since passed and BCI has fallen substantially behind schedule on the project.
		 
The project has run into numerous difficulties:
		 
Several subcontractors have issued stop notices due to BCI's failure to pay, which currently include Arming-Johnson in the amount of $101,168.00 (Attachment 5), and J.L. Shumaker Co. in the amount of$167,319.80 (Attachment 6).
Some subcontractors have not returned to continue critical path work.
The project remains off-schedule and no realistic recovery schedule is in place or has been proposed by BCI.
There is an inadequate level of manpower on the project and at the site to complete the project within a reasonable amount of time.
		 
District staff and the District's Construction Manager have met with BCI to discuss project progress and to allow BCI an opportunity to remedy the delays or, alternatively, to provide a feasible plan for remedying the delays and completing the project within a reasonable amount of time.  District staff met with BCI on July 25, 2012, to discuss the gravity of the matter and to discuss BCI's development of a feasible plan for completing the project.  At that time BCI was asked to submit to the District no later than August 6 a plan to finance the completion of the project, a new critical path method (CPM) schedule for the project showing the actual date that the project will finish.  A copy of a July 25, 2012, follow-up letter from the District's Construction Manager (O'Connor Construction Management) to BCI is included as Attachment 1 and which details inadequate manpower and staffing levels at the project site.  BCI subsequently provided a recovery schedule (Attachment 2) showing projected beneficial occupancy by the District on January 17, 2013.  BCI has not provided the requested financial plan.
		 
The District's Construction Manager has had subsequent communications with BCI regarding the need to adhere to the schedule and to adequately staff the project.  See attached August 17, 2012 (Attachment 3), correspondence to BCI further documenting inadequate manpower and staffing levels by BCI at the Project.  BCI's response to that letter is included as Attachment 4.
		 
The Project is well behind schedule; BCI is making only slow and minimal progress towards completion and according to the Construction Manager the Project is inadequately staffed by subcontractors and little to no critical path work progress is being made.  Two new stop notices were received by the District last week (see Attachments 5 and 6).
		 
Brief Contract Analysis
		 
Section 24.1.1 of the Contract General Conditions provides that the District may terminate the contract and/or terminate the contractor's right to perform the work of the contract for cause based on, among other things, (i) BCI's failure to execute the work with sufficient diligence as will ensure completion within the time specified in the contract, (ii) BCI's failure to complete the work by the scheduled completion date, (iii) BCI's failure to supply enough properly skilled workers or materials to complete the work in the time specified, (iv) BCI's  failure to make prompt payment to subcontractors.
		 
Upon a determination that any of the grounds for termination exist, the District may serve written notice upon BCI and the Surety of the District's termination of the contract and/or the right to perform the work of the contract.  The notice must contain the reasons for termination.  After service of the notice, BCI shall have three (3) days to cure the violations and to cease the violative conditions.
		 
Upon termination, the District may immediately serve written notice of tender upon the Surety which will then have the right to take over and perform the project upon notice to the District.
	 
	 
	 
Funding Source:
Measure E
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined
	 
Recommendation:
Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board of Trustees take action based on the above and attached information and that the Board determines on those bases and on such other information as may be presented to the Board that BCI: (1) has failed to execute the Work under the Contract or any separable part thereof with sufficient diligence as would have ensured the Project's completion within the time specified, (2) has failed to complete the Work under the Contract within the time specified; (3) has persistently or repeatedly failed to supply enough properly skilled workers to complete the Work in the time specified; and (4) has failed to make prompt payment to Subcontractors, or for material, or for labor.  Administration further recommends that on the basis of the foregoing the Board delegates to Administration the authority and power to terminate the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract and to serve written notice upon BCI and its Surety of District's termination of the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract in accordance with the terms of the Contract, which notice shall contain the above grounds and such other grounds as Administration may determine after further investigation.
items.item_recommendation: Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board of Trustees take action based on the above and attached information and that the Board determines on those bases and on such other information as may be presented to the Board that BCI: (1) has failed to execute the Work under the Contract or any separable part thereof with sufficient diligence as would have ensured the Project's completion within the time specified, (2) has failed to complete the Work under the Contract within the time specified; (3) has persistently or repeatedly failed to supply enough properly skilled workers to complete the Work in the time specified; and (4) has failed to make prompt payment to Subcontractors, or for material, or for labor. Administration further recommends that on the basis of the foregoing the Board delegates to Administration the authority and power to terminate the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract and to serve written notice upon BCI and its Surety of District's termination of the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract in accordance with the terms of the Contract, which notice shall contain the above grounds and such other grounds as Administration may determine after further investigation.
